awd_titl_txt: Combinatorial and Tropical Degenerations of Classical Moduli Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Tropical geometry is a young and rapidly growing area in mathematics, rooted in algebraic geometry, complex analysis, commutative algebra, and combinatorics, with applications in computer science, biology, and statistical physics, in addition to other areas of mathematics. The recent decade has seen tremendous development in the subject that both established the field as an area in its own right and unveiled its deep connections to numerous branches of pure and applied mathematics. Moduli spaces are spaces of parameters that classify algebro-geometric mathematical objects, such as varieties, maps between varieties, and vector bundles. This research project aims at providing a new combinatorial perspective on classical moduli spaces and their interplay with nonarchimedean analytic geometry. Computational challenges in this direction are its driving force. The primary goal is to deepen understanding of these objects and develop new techniques to analyze such abstract spaces through concrete computations in tropical geometry. Several topics investigated in this project witness the interdisciplinary nature of the subject and are suitable for research in collaboration with graduate students.

Tropical geometry provides a framework for solving algebro-geometric problems using concrete combinatorial tools: algebraic varieties are replaced by weighted, balanced polyhedral complexes. These objects preserve just enough data about the original varieties to remain meaningful, while discarding much of their complexity. Their combinatorics depends strongly on the embeddings of our varieties. By contrast, the Berkovich space or the space of valuations is independent of all such choices. By choosing appropriate coordinates, the geometry and topology of these valuations are reflected in rich combinatorial properties on the polyhedral side, including connectedness, shellability, etc. Thus, the intricacies of the original space turn into exciting combinatorial problems. Tropicalizations resulting from these nice embeddings are said to be faithful. The project aims at developing certificates for local faithfulness by means of initial (Groebner) degenerations of the variety. The notion of faithfulness near that point then turns into desirable properties of this degeneration. Not surprisingly, validating these properties requires a deep understanding of the combinatorics and geometry of the initial degenerations. Thus, the need to find effective methods for constructing or detecting faithfulness is at the core of tropical geometry. The project will develop such program for several important classes of examples: Grassmannians, moduli of curves, del Pezzo surfaces, Fano schemes and cluster varieties.

por.por_cntn:
Results from research supported by this grant include six articles, three of which are published. In addition, three additional papers are currently in preparation and the core of the research was conducted during the tenure of this award. The aforementioned publications cover a wide range of topics, including topology of isolated surface singularities, work on tropical analogs of classical results involving bitangents to smooth plan quartic curves and the 27 lines on the cubic surface, initial degenerations of Grasmmannians, and tropical geometry of genus two curves, including the construction of tropical analogs of the classical Igusa invariants. Several articles by young researchers have been inspired by these works.

The PI has made a conscious decision to make all code (on Macaulay 2, Polymake, Sage and Singular) developed for publications funded by this grant freely available on two Supplementary materials websites. Careful documentation allows other researchers to adapt these scripts and the combinatorial data produced by them to their specific needs.

Funds from this grant have been used to support one graduate student in his 3rd year of study for one semester. Funds were also use to support travel by the PI to visit collaborators and give talks at 12 international conferences, one six-hour minicourse for graduate students (in University of Lille, France)  and 11 specialized seminars and colloquia presentations in the US. Thanks to these efforts, the research that resulted from this award has been disseminated widely within the mathematics research community.

Over the period of NSF support, the PI has supervised two Masters students and mentored two postodocs, one of which is female. She is currently a tenure-track faculty at U. Otterbein. In addition, the PI has made active efforts to recruit PhD students by developing three problem-based reading courses, which involved 10 first and second year PhD students (included one female and one Latino student). In addition, the PI was the team leader of a group of four female researchers (three of them at early career stages) during the first Women in Algebraic Geometry workshop. The work involved a research project proposed by the PI with a heavy computational component.

The PI organized a special session (with 20 talks) during the AMS Sectional Meeting that took place at her home university in 2018. The coorganizers were two postdocs at nearby institutions. Several of the speakers were young researchers. In addition, with three colleagues, she coorganized the third installment of a series of workshops on Graduate Advising. Its target audience was junior faculty from US based institutions who were starting to advise graduate students. The event featured a mix of panels by experts and group discussions with concrete case studies. Outcomes were shared with the community at large through a piece written for the Early Career section of the Notices of the AMS.
